module.p: thig come is an irregular simple verb. It generally denotes a (proximal) event of motion along a trajectory, towards the speaker or centre of discourse (cf. the equivalent distal verb rach go).

section.p:
The principal parts of thig are –
thig – future independent will come
thàinig – past independent came
tighinn – verbal noun coming

section.p:
Notes –
The dependent forms in tig- and tàinig- are pronounced as if they were spelled dig- and dàinig-.
Alternative verbal nouns in traditional Gaelic are teachd and tighean.

The subject of thig is usually a noun or pronoun denoting one or more human beings moving towards the speaker (or other deictic centre) under their own volition –
Thàinig Raonaid. Rachel came.
Cha tig na balaich. The boys won’t come.
An tigeadh iad? Would they come?

Some examples –
proper nouns –
pedagogical examples –
An tàinig Iain fhathast? | An tàinig Beathag fhathast? | Is ann a thàinig Iain anmoch. | Thàinig Iain gun fhiosta dhomh. | Cha tàinig ach Anna. | Tha iad a’ ràdh gun tàinig Iain.
Has John come yet? | Has Rebecca come yet? | John really did come late. | John came unknown to me. | Only Ann came. | They say that John came. td. 39, 50, 57, 72, 75, 105
An tàinig Màiri an-raoir?
Did Mary arrive last night? td. 578
common nouns –
pedagogical examples –
Thàinig am Poileas agus rug iad air a’ mheàirleach.
The police came and they caught the robber. td. 39
pronouns –
first person –
pedagogical examples –
Thig mi a-nochd.
I shall come tonight. td. 578
second person –
pedagogical examples –
Nach tig thu a-steach?
Won’t you come in? td. 578
An tig thu a chèilidh orm a-nochd? Chì sinn thu nuair a thig thu.
Will you come to visit me tonight? We will see you when you come. td. 118
third person –
pedagogical examples –
Thàinig iad dhachaigh. Cha tàinig iad riamh. | Thàinig iad a-steach. | A-nis càite a bheil Dòmhnall? Thàinig esan mar-thà. | Tha i a-muigh an sin a’ bruidhinn ach cha tàinig i a-staigh fhathast. | Thàinig e ged a bha e sgìth. | An tig iad?
They came home. They never came. | They came in. | Now where’s Donald. He has come already. | She is out there talking but she hasn’t come in yet. | He came although he was tired. | Will they come? td. 38, 196, 50, ibid, 197, 119
Thàinig e don doras. An tig iad a dh’aithghearr? Ma thig e, an tig ise cuideachd?
He came to the door. Will they come soon? If he comes, will she come too? td. 578
Cha tig iad dhachaigh dìreach an dèidh na sgoile.
They will not come home directly after school. td. 198
relativised subjects –
pedagogical examples –
Is e Seumas a thàinig a-staigh.
It is James that came in. td. 57
biblical examples –
A Nis is iad so ainmeanna chloinn Israeil, a thàinig do’n Eiphit; thàinig gach duine agus a theaghlach maille re Iacob: Reuben, Simeon, Lebhi, agus Iudah, Isachar, Sebulun, agus Beniamin, Dan, agus Naphtali, Gad, agus Aser. [...]
Now these are the names of the children of Israel, which came into Egypt; every man and his household came with Jacob. Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah, Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin, Dan, and Naphtali, Gad, and Asher. [...] [KJV] Ecsodus I.1–5
imperatives –
pedagogical examples –
Thig a-staigh. Tha e fuar an-diugh. | Na tig(ibh) an seo. Thigeadh Anna. | Thig(ibh) a-steach.
Come in. It’s cold today. | Don’t come here. Let Ann come. | Come in. td. 34, 42, 196

When responding to a question, the subject can be dropped –
An tàinig thu? Did you come?
Thàinig. Yes, I did.
Cha tàinig. No, I didn’t.
Cò às an tig Raonaid? Where will Rachel come from?
Thig às a’ bhaile. She will come from (the) town.

Some examples –
yes/no questions –
pedagogical examples –
An tàinig Màiri an-raoir? Thàinig. / Cha tàinig. An tig iad a dh’aithghearr? | Thig. / Cha tig.
Did Mary arrive last night? Yes, she did. / No, she didn’t. | Will they come soon? Yes, they will. / No, they won’t. td. 578, ibid
An tig thu a chèilidh orm a-nochd? Thig. | An tig iad? Thig. / Cha tig.
Will you come to visit me tonight? Yes, I will. | Will they come? Yes, they will. / No, they won’t. td. 118, 119

Examples with non-human subjects –
A bheil fios agaibh cuin a thàinig an trèan?
Do you know when the train came? td. 78
Thuit e anns a’ chadal às nach tig dùsgadh.
He fell into the sleep from which comes no awakening. td. 49
Chì thu amannan nan trèanaichean air a’ bhòrd-shanais ach cluinnidh tu caismeachd mus tig an trèan a-staigh dhan an stèisean.
You will see the train times on the notice board but you will hear an announcement before the train comes into the station. td. 134

Unlike rach go, thig occurs frequently without any complement, with the trajectory of motion understood from context –
Thàinig Raonaid. Rachel came [to(wards) or alongside the current deictic centre]. / Mary arrived.

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Cha tàinig iad riamh. | An tàinig Iain fhathast? Thàinig am Poileas agus rug iad air a’ mheàirleach. | Thigeadh Anna. | An tàinig Beathag fhathast? | A-nis càite a bheil Dòmhnall? Thàinig esan mar-thà. | Is ann a thàinig Iain anmoch. | Thàinig Iain gun fhiosta dhomh. | Cha tàinig ach Anna. | A bheil fios agaibh cuin a thàinig an trèan? | Thàinig e ged a bha e sgìth. | | Tha iad a’ ràdh gun tàinig Iain. | Chì sinn thu nuair a thig thu. | An tig iad?
They never came. | Has John come yet? The police came and they caught the robber. | Let Ann come. | Has Rebecca come yet? | Now where’s Donald. He has come already. | John really did come late. | John came unknown to me. | Only Ann came. | Do you know when the train came? | He came although he was tired. | They say that John came. | We will see you when you come. | Will they come? td. 38, 39, 42, 50, 57, 72, 75, 78, 197, 105, 118, 119
An tàinig Màiri an-raoir? Thig mi a-nochd. An tig iad a dh’aithghearr? Ma thig e, an tig ise cuideachd?
Did Mary arrive last night? I shall come tonight. Will they come soon? If he comes, will she come too? td. 578
biblical examples –
A Nis is iad so ainmeanna chloinn Israeil, a thàinig do’n Eiphit; thàinig gach duine agus a theaghlach maille re Iacob: Reuben, Simeon, Lebhi, agus Iudah, [...] Agus na h-anman uile a thàinig a mach a leasraidh Iacoib, bu deich agus tri fichead anam iad; oir bha Ioseph ’san Eiphit a cheana. [...]
Now these are the names of the children of Israel, which came into Egypt; every man and his household came with Jacob. Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah, [...] And all the souls that came out of the loins of Jacob were seventy souls: for Joseph was in Egypt already. [KJV] Ecsodus I.1–5
Otherwise, thig usually takes one or more complements – prepositional phrases or adverbs.

Concrete uses of thig involve a material (generally animate, volitional) subject moving along a trajectory/path in three-dimensional physical space (generally towards the speaker or other deictic centre), often with a specific goal/purpose in mind.
A complement of concrete thig can denote the physical trajectory of motion itself, usually with respect to one or more reference objects.

There are a number of prepositions which can be used to introduce concrete path complements of thig –
thig à ... come out of ...
thig bho ... come from ...
thig dha [do/a] ... come (in)to ... –
pedagogical examples –
Thàinig e don doras.
He came to the door. td. 578
Chì thu amannan nan trèanaichean air a’ bhòrd-shanais ach cluinnidh tu caismeachd mus tig an trèan a-staigh dhan an stèisean.
You will see the train times on the notice board but you will hear an announcement before the train comes into the station. td. 134
biblical examples –
A Nis is iad so ainmeanna chloinn Israeil, a thàinig do’n Eiphit; thàinig gach duine agus a theaghlach maille re Iacob: Reuben, Simeon, Lebhi, agus Iudah, Isachar, Sebulun, agus Beniamin, Dan, agus Naphtali, Gad, agus Aser. [...]
Now these are the names of the children of Israel, which came into Egypt; every man and his household came with Jacob. Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah, Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin, Dan, and Naphtali, Gad, and Asher. [...] [KJV] Ecsodus I.1–5

There are many adverbs (and prepositional compounds) which can serve as the complement of thig, denoting a concrete trajectory –
thig a-mach come out(side) (cf. thig a-muigh)
thig a-nall come over here (cf. thig a-null)
thig a-nuas come down (cf. thig sìos)
thig a-steach come in(side) (cf. thig a-staigh)
thig an·seo come here (cf. thig an·sin)
thig dhachaigh come home
thig faisg air ... come near, approach
thig a dh’ionnsaigh ... come (to visit?)
A complement of concrete thig can denote the purpose of the motion, the reason why the volitional subject decided to act in that way.

Some examples –
Tha daoine a’ tighinn a-nochd gu biadh.
People are coming to dinner this evening. td. 35
Cò a thig gu ar faicinn?
Who will come to see us? td. 578
An tig thu a chèilidh orm a-nochd?
Will you come to visit me tonight? td. 118
cf. thig air làithean saora come on holiday
Abstract uses of thig do not involve physical motion along a concrete spatial trajectory.

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Thuit e anns a’ chadal às nach tig dùsgadh.
He fell into the sleep from which comes no awakening. td. 49

Forms of thig can be used with a wide range of adverbial modifiers –
temporal –
pedagogical examples –
Cha tàinig iad riamh. | An tàinig Beathag fhathast? Tha i a-muigh an sin a’ bruidhinn ach cha tàinig i a-staigh fhathast. A-nis càite a bheil Dòmhnall? Thàinig esan mar-thà. | Is ann a thàinig Iain anmoch. | A bheil fios agaibh cuin a thàinig an trèan? | An tig thu a chèilidh orm a-nochd? | Cha tig iad dhachaigh dìreach an dèidh na sgoile.
They never came. | Has Rebecca come yet? She is out there talking but she hasn’t come in yet. Now where’s Donald. He has come already. | John really did come late. | Do you know when the train came? | Will you come to visit me tonight? | They will not come home directly after school. td. 38, 50, 57, 78, 118, 198
An tàinig Màiri an-raoir? Thig mi a-nochd. An tig iad a dh’aithghearr?
Did Mary arrive last night? I shall come tonight. Will they come soon? td. 578
accompanying –
thig maille ri ... come along with ...
concessive/contrastive –
pedagogical examples –
Thàinig e ged a bha e sgìth.
He came although he was tired. td. 197
conditional –
pedagogical examples –
Ma thig e, an tig ise cuideachd?
If he comes, will she come too? td. 578
other –
pedagogical examples –
Thàinig Iain gun fhiosta dhomh.
John came unknown to me. td. 72
Ma thig e, an tig ise cuideachd?
If he comes, will she come too? td. 578

li.gd: Tha i a-muigh an sin a’ bruidhinn ach cha tàinig i a-staigh fhathast. Tha i a’ tighinn a dh’aithghearr.
li.tr: She is out there talking but she hasn’t come in yet. She’s coming soon.

li.gd: Bha e a’ tighinn na b’ fhaisge.
Tha Màiri a’ tighinn a-nall à Glaschu.
li.tr: Mary is coming over here from Glasgow.

li.gd: Bha e a’ tighinn a-mach às an taigh.
li.tr: He was coming out of the house.

li.gd: Chaidh e a-steach don togalach às an robh an t-seinn a’ tighinn.
li.tr: He entered the building from which the singing was coming.

li.gd: Tha mac mo pheathar agus bràthair m’ athar a’ tighinn gar n-ionnsaigh air an lathaichean saora.
li.tr: My nephew and my uncle are coming (to visit us) on their holidays.
